text.headline: 10000ft overview of the Key Manuscripts
text.text: Explore a sweeping timeline of the key manuscripts that went into the Bible - from tablets to letters to the psalms.

text.headline: The Ten Commandments
text.text:
Carved in stone at Mount Sinai, the Ten Commandments were God's covenant with His people.

Delivered through Moses, they formed the moral and spiritual backbone of ancient Israel.

Simple yet profound, these words have echoed through millennia of law, ethics and faith.

Divine instruction that still speaks today.

text.headline: The Old Testament books
text.text:
Spanning over a thousand years, the Old Testament tells the story of God's covenant with His people.

From creation to exile, law to prophecy, its 39 books are filled with wisdom, history, poetry and promise.

Every page points forward - to a Messiah yet to come!

It's the foundation upon which the New Testament stands.

text.headline: The Septuagint
text.text:
Ptolemy II commissioned the translation of the Hebrew Scriptures (the Torah)into Greek, known as the Septuagint.

Completed by Jewish scholars in Alexandria, it made the Scriptures accessible to the wider Greek-speaking world.

The Septuagint later became widely used among early Christians.

text.headline: The Dead Sea Scrolls
text.text:
The Dead Sea Scrolls, discovered between 1947-1956 AD near the Dead Sea in Israel, contain fragments from every book of the Hebrew Bible except Esther.

The Isaiah Scrolls proved to be word-for-word identical with the standard Hebrew Bible in more than 95% of the text, confirming the accuracy and reliability of the Masoretic Text.

text.headline: The New Testament letters
text.text:
Written by apostles and early church leaders, the New Testament letters guided first-century believers.

From Paul's bold theology to Peter's encouragement and John's love, these epistles shaped Christian life and doctrine.

Circulated among churches, copied, and cherished, they carried truth across the Roman world.

They remain living words for the Church today.

text.headline: Rylands Papyrus
text.text:
The Rylands Papyrus is the oldest known fragment of the New Testament - just a few verses of John's Gospel.

Tiny and worn, yet it powerfully confirms that the gospel was circulating within a generation of the eyewitnesses.

Discovered in Egypt, it bridges the gap between original writing and surviving copies.

text.headline: Codex Vaticanus
text.text:
Housed in the Vatican Library, Codex Vaticanus is one of the oldest nearly complete Greek Bibles.

Dating to the 300s AD, it preserves much of the Septuagint and New Testament with remarkable accuracy.

It's a priceless window into the early transmission of Scripture.

Still today, scholars turn to it for trusted textual foundations.

text.headline: Codex Sinaiticus
text.text:
Codex Sinaiticus is one of the most important books in the world.

Handwritten well over 1600 years ago, the manuscript contains the Christian Bible in Greek, including the oldest complete copy of the New Testament.

text.headline: Athanasius of Alexandria
text.text:
In a landmark Easter letter, Bishop Athanasius listed the 27 books of the New Testament we recognize today.

Amid fierce debates and heresies, he defended the divinity of Christ and the authority of Scripture.

His canon list was the first to match our current New Testament.

text.headline: Vulgate
text.text:
Commissioned by Pope Damasus I, Jerome translated the Bible into Latin from Hebrew and Greek.

His work, the Vulgate, became the standard Bible of the Western Church for over a thousand years.

More than a translation, it unified Scripture across the Roman Empire.

A foundational moment for biblical transmission and Church history.

text.headline: Codex Leningrad
text.text:
The Codex Leningrad is the oldest complete manuscript of the Hebrew Bible still in existence.

Meticulously copied by Masoretic scribes, it preserves the Hebrew text with extraordinary care.

It remains a foundational reference for modern Old Testament translations.

An enduring testament to the precision and preservation of Scripture through the ages.

text.headline: Wycliffe Bible
text.text:
John Wycliffe believed everyone should access God's Word in their own tongue.

His followers translated the Bible from Latin into English - by hand and against opposition.

Though banned and burned, the Wycliffe Bible lit a flame for reform and literacy.

A bold step toward the Reformation, centuries before it began.

text.headline: The Gutenberg Bible
text.text:
The Gutenberg Bible was the first book ever printed with movable type - a technological and spiritual breakthrough.

Printed in Latin, it marked the dawn of the printed word and mass communication.

It made the Bible more accessible and paved the way for the Reformation.

text.headline: Martin Luther
text.text:
Martin Luther sparked a revolution when he nailed 95 theses to a church door in 1517.

He challenged corruption and proclaimed that salvation comes by faith alone.

Luther's German Bible put Scripture into the hands of everyday people.

His bold stand lit the fire of the Protestant Reformation and changed history forever.

text.headline: Tyndale Bible
text.text:
William Tyndale risked his life to translate the Bible from Hebrew and Greek into English.

His work brought the Scriptures to common people for the first time - clear, bold and forbidden.

Tyndale was executed, but his words lived on - nearly 90% of the King James Bible echoes his phrasing.

He gave his life so others could read God's Word.

text.headline: The Geneva Bible
text.text:
Birthed by English reformers in exile, the Geneva Bible was the first to include study notes and numbered verses.

Beloved by Puritans and carried to the New World, it shaped minds and nations.

Its language was sharp, its theology boldâ€”used by Shakespeare and quoted by revolutionaries.

text.headline: King James Bible
text.text:
Commissioned by King James I of England, over 50 scholars united to translate the Bible into majestic English.

Published in 1611, based on the earlier work of William Tyndale, it became one of the most influential books in history.

Its poetic language shaped both faith and the English-speaking world for centuries.

A monumental work rooted in reverence, precision and legacy.
